Benkadi est un regroupement de femmes  du quartier de Mousabougou de la ville Koutiala qui vivent dans de grandes familles traditionnelles avec leurs maris, enfants et autres parents et ont en moyenne 44 ans, sont mariées et mères d’au moins 6 enfants.
Ce groupe de femmes fait le commerce de pagnes, d’habits de toutes sortes et des friperies. 
Pour augmenter la taille de leurs activités, les membres ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso il y a 3 ans. Elles sont à leur sixième prêt de groupe et tous les prêts précédents  ont été bien remboursés.  
Adama Nantoumé qui est un membre du groupe Benkadi vend des habits de toutes sortes : pagnes Dogon, bazins, friperies…, et elle fait également du tricotage de laine (une activité  dans laquelle elle est  aussi sollicitée).  
Elle compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, des pagnes Dogon à Bandiagara, des bazins et quelques friperies à Bamako. Elle vend ses articles en détail et au comptant au grand marché de Koutiala, à la maison,  à une clientèle diverse et variée. 
Tandis que Les membres du groupe comptent réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 160 000FCFA  chacune au  cours de ce cycle, Adama Nantoumé  compte réaliser 190 000FCFA.  
En plus du remboursement des prêts, elles utilisent une partie du revenu  pour faire face aux dépenses courantes de la famille.
texts.en:
Benkadi is a grouping of women from the Mousabougou district of the town of Koutiala; they live in large traditional families with their husbands, children and other relatives, they average 44 years of age and are married with at least six children each.

This group of women sell "pagnes" (a West African term for highly colourful pieces of fabric) as well as all sorts of clothing and second hand clothes. In order to expand their businesses, the members of the group decided to join Soro Yiriwaso's loan program three years ago. They are on their sixth group loan and all the previous loans were repaid in full. 

Adama Nantoumé, who is a member of the Benkadi group, sells all sorts of clothing: Dogon "pagnes", damask fabric, second-hand clothing ..., and she also does wool knitting (an activity for which she is equally in demand). She is planning to use her loan to buy Dogon "pagnes" in Bandiagara, as well as damask fabric and some second-hand clothes in Bamako. She sells her goods on a retail basis for cash at the large market in Koutiala and at home to a diverse customer base. 

While the members of the group are expecting to make a monthly profit of 160,000FCFA each during this cycle, Mrs. Nantoumé is planning to make 190,000FCFA. As well as repaying their loans, the women use part of their income to cover their families' day-to-day expenses.

loans.use: Purchase of clothes

loans.name: Vong

texts.en: Vong S. is a 53-year-old woman who currently lives in Phnom Penh City, Cambodia. She and her husband are local farmers. This old couple lives with five  children, four of whom are single, and one is married. They earn their living by planting various crops on their own farmland. Vong S. is currently concerned that her old motorbike is often broken. She wants to purchase a new motorcycle in order to replace the broken one, but her savings account is not enough to make this possible. Because of this reason, Vong S. is applying for a loan from Kiva.

loans.use: To purchase a new motorcycle, to replace the broken one.

loans.name: Cosmos Group

texts.es: Este grupo se llama Cosmos está integrado por 9 clientas, en él se encuentra L. señora Mariana N.. Tiene 30 años, estudió hasta L. secundaria, y es comerciante, venD. zapatos por catálogo. ElL. tiene 2 hijos, L. sra nos platica que inició su negocio hace 2 años debido a L. situación económica y a que uno D. sus hijos requería tratamiento médico. Con el prestamo quiere surtir mercancía dado que incrementó sus pedidos. En este mismo grupo se encuentra L. señora Rosa Maria V. D. 40 años, estudió L. primaria, es comerciante y tuvo 7 hijos. L. Sra siempre ha trabajado vendiendo diversos productos ropa y productos D. temporada, nos platica que lleva 16 años con el negocio ya que debido a que L. familia era numerosa, L. sra  Rosa se vió en L. necesidad D. apoyar en el gasto familiar. L. Sra. Mariana vió que los pedidos iban en ascenso y solicitó el crédito para invertir en L. compra D. ropa D. temporada.
texts.en:
This group is called Cosmos and has 9 members. 

Mariana N. is one of the group's members.  She is 30 years old and studied up to high school level.  She is a saleswoman and sells shoes through a catalog.  She has two children.  Mariana tells us that she started her business 2 years ago because of her economic situation and because one of her children needed medical treatment.  Mariana would like to use her loan to stock up with merchandise as her orders have increased.

Rosa Maria Vázquez is another member of this group.  She is 40 years old, studied to elementary school level, is a saleswoman and has 7 children.  She has always worked selling different products such as clothes and seasonal products.  She tells us that she has been in this business for 16 years since, as she has a large family, Rosa has to support her family's expenses.  She saw that her orders were increasing and requested this loan so that she could invest in buying seasonal clothes.

loans.use: To invest in buying merchandise

loans.name: Cheas

texts.en: Making baskets is a part of 52-year-old Cheas C.’s daily activities for earning an income. Cheas C. and her husband currently buy raw materials to make baskets to sell in her house. They also buy baskets from other weavers at a reasonable price and resell them to gain extra profits. They have done this since 1985. Cheas C. is an older mother who has four children. Two of her children are studying in the public school, while the other two are employed as garment workers. Now, Cheas C. is not comfortable for living because her house is getting old and it needs to repair. Because of lacking money, But Teav has decided to ask for a loan from Kiva to add her personal savings to buy woods for repairing her old house.

loans.use: To buy wood for repairing her old house.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy food preparation ingredients.

loans.name: Pharn

texts.en: Pharn N., 51, is married and resides with her husband and three children in Prey Veng Province, Cambodia, an area known as one of the largest rice producing regions in Cambodia. N. is a housewife while her husband is a motor-taxi driver, earning an income of USD 2.5 per day to help cover the family expenses. Each month, the family has to spend USD 44 on food and USD 20 on other necessary expenses. N. is requesting a loan of USD 600 to purchase a motorbike for the family's use. In the future, she would like to use the additional income to repair her house. This will be her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike for the family's use

loans.name: Bambisanani Group

texts.en:
Fikile is 28 years old and single, with 3 children between the ages of 1 and 7 years old. She cares for one relative. She runs a retail business at her home in Nkandla in Kwa Zulu Natal, South Africa. In the photo she is raising her right hand.

She sells chickens at her home and has been in this business for 2 years. She also receives income from the government's child support grant. She says that the main challenge to her business is customers who buy on credit and fail to pay on time.  She requested this loan through Women’s Development Businesses to buy chickens. She says that the extra income from this loan will help her make more profit and support her children. In the future, she hopes to make more profit and have employees to help her.

She adds that she does not have a shelter to sell her stock, and would like to know if WDB and Kiva can help her build her own shelter because now she is selling on the streets.

loans.use: To buy chickens

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy a variety of items that she needs for her embroidery business

loans.name: Hermine

texts.en:
Hermine H. lives with her husband, mother-in-law and 2 children in Katnaghbyur village of Lori region. Unable to find a job locally, Hermine’s husband goes abroad for seasonal work.

Hermine keeps a cattle farm, grows potatoes and fruit trees which generate the family’s main income. Hermine would like to increase the income by purchasing 3 young bulls.

loans.use: to buy 3 young bulls

loans.name: Development Group

texts.en: Adama K., who leads this five-person loan group, is 35 years old and lives in the city of Makeni. She is married, has four children and has made a living by selling ready-to-wear-clothes for the last several years. She will use her portion of this loan, her first, to expand her business by buying more clothing to sell to her customers. The other members of this group will also use their portions of this loan to expand their businesses and improve their living conditions.

loans.use: To expand several small businesses.

loans.name: Antonia

texts.es:
Antonia, resiD. en El Divisadero, departamento  Morazán, se dedica a la venta D. leche, cuajada y quesadillas, también tiene un molino para moler maíz, ella vive con su esposo y dos hijos.
Actualmente solicita un préstamo para comprar productos D. primera necesidad, como frijoles, arroz, aceite, también necesita una parte para realizar una fosa séptica, pagar mano D. obra y arena, ladrillo y cemento.
Su objetivo es mejorar la calidad D. vida D. su familia y a través D. su trabajo espera contar con todo lo necesario para sus hijos.
texts.en:
Antonia lives in El Divisadero, in Morazán department.  She sells milk, curd and quesadillas.  She also has a mill for grinding corn.  She lives with her husband and two children.

Antonia is currently requesting a loan to buy essentials such as beans, rice and oil.  She also needs some of the money to build a septic tank, pay labor costs and buy sand, bricks and cement.

Antonia's goal is to improve her family's quality of life and, through her work, she hopes to have everything she needs for her children.

loans.use: to buy beans, rice and oil

loans.name: Melecia

texts.en:
Melecia is 53 years old and married with eight children.  Melecia works very hard to provide for them.

Melecia runs a sari-sari (variety) store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 10,000 loan through NWTF to buy groceries for her store to sell.

Melecia has been in this business for two years and sells a variety of items such as softdrinks, candies and other groceries. 

In the future, Melecia would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy groceries for her sari-sari store to sell

loans.name: Cora

texts.en:
Cora is from the village of Sinonoc, Sinacaban, Misamis Occidental. She is 33 years old. Cora is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Cora owns & operates transportation services. The main source of income for the business comes from operating tricycle (three-wheeled) transport services. Cora has been engaged in her business for over one year and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2011, Cora joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Cora is requesting a loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to purchase tires and other accessories. This will be the first loan taken out by Cora from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has seven branches  covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase tires and other accessories.

loans.name: Nheap

texts.en:
Nheap is 57 years old. She is a vegetable seller with her husband. Their income is $8 per day. They have six children, and they are 30, 28, 25, 23, 21, and 17 years old. Five of them are studying and one is working in an organization for $7 per day. 

Every month, she has to spend $85 on food, $15 on utilities, $70 on school fees, $25 on transportation and $19 for other expenses. 

She would like to request a loan of $700 to buy rice seed and other seeds for planting to sell. 

She wants to send all of her children to study until they finish university, so she needs to make more income to keep for them when they need it for their school fees.

loans.use: To buy rice seed and other planting seeds.

loans.name: Daysi

texts.es: Daysi trabaja  como cajera en una empresa privada. El crédito lo requiere para el aumento de un anticrético en la casa donde vive, pues el dueño de casa le ha subido el monto del anticrético (Anticrético es una figura legal por la cual el dueño de casa permite a otra persona vivir en la casa por un plazo determinado y por un monto total pagadero por adelantado y que será devuelto al cabo del plazo establecido en el contrato). Vive en anticrético en una casa ubicada en la zona de Alto San Pedro  de la ciudad de La Paz; es soltera y no tiene hijos. Esta es la segunda vez que su crédito se canaliza a través de Kiva.
texts.en: Daysi works as a cashier in a private company.  She needs this loan to increase the 'anticrético' payment for the house that she rents, as the owner of the house has increased the amount of the 'anticrético' ('anticrético' is a system whereby the owner of a house allows another person to live in it for a pre-determined period of time, for a sum of money which is paid in advance and then returned to the tenant at the end of the term established in the contract).  Daysi lives in a house which she rents 'en anticrético'.  It is located in Alto San Pedro district, in the city of La Paz.  She is single and doesn't have any children.  This is the second time that she has had a loan through Kiva.

loans.use: to increase the 'anticrético' sum for the house where she lives

loans.name: Duo Las Margaritas Group

texts.es: Duo Las margaritas: Margarita es la lider del Grupo ella se dedica a la venta D. productos comestibles desD. ya hace varios años, ella nos cuenta que esta contenta porque poco a poco a salido adelante en su negocio y sus clientes pococ a poco ban aumentando esta solicitando este credito para la compra  D. productos comestibles para surtir mas su negocio ya que sus clientes le piden productos que ella no tiene entonces esta convencida D. que le falta capital para trabajar.al igual que la siguiente socia ella se dedica a la crianza D. animales y esta solicitando este credito para la compra D. animales para crianza.
texts.en:
'Las Margaritas' Group.

Margarita is the leader of this group.  She has been selling food products for several years.  She tells us that she is happy because she has gradually gotten ahead in her business and her number of customers has gradually increased.  She is requesting this loan to buy food products so that she can further stock her business as her customers ask her for products that she doesn't have.  She is certain that she needs more capital to work.

The other member of this group raises animals.  She is requesting this loan to buy animals to raise.

loans.use: to buy food products to sell

loans.name: Jasper Willy

texts.en:
Jasper, age 41, operates a food sales business in his home district of Bushenyi in western Uganda. At first, start-up capital was a major impediment, as Jasper sought to obtain a footing in this lucrative area of business. His drive, discipline, diligence, and desire were strong enough, but the father of one says the savings from his first business - charcoal sales - were minimal. This, to all intents and purposes, rendered it hard for his efforts to take root. The tide turned, however, when a close friend lent him financial assistance for his endeavors, which allowed his food trade sales business to succeed. He now sells his food items in food markets around Bushenyi.
 
Jasper is a stickler for hard work and he evaluates his strengths and weaknesses on an ongoing basis. He takes pride in the fact that he gets along with people of all different personalities and persuasions. Jasper also ekes out a modest additional income from his small fish sales business.

His biggest challenge in the few years he has been in operation is the rising costs of doing business. Rental costs for food stalls in the markets are high. Because most food prices have gone up, recent demand has been plummeting. This has adversely affected Jasper's business. However, Jasper sees a silver lining in all this and chooses to remain upbeat. 

Weekly, Jasper says his business's gross sales revenue totals up to 120,000 Ugandan shillings.

Jasper says this Kiva loan will allow him to purchase more food items to offer for sale, such as maize, cassava, sweet potatoes, yams, Irish potatoes, pineapples, cabbage, and paw-paws.

loans.use: to purchase more food items to offer for sale, such as maize, cassava, sweet potatoes, yams, Irish potatoes, pineapples, cabbage, and paw-paws

loans.name: Leang

texts.en:
Leang is 32 years old and married. She has two school-aged children. 

She works very hard to provide for her family. Leang has run a retail store in the Siem Reap province of Cambodia where she sells a variety of items such as rice, sugar, soap and other grocery items like snacks and noodles.

Leang is requesting a loan from Kiva in order to buy additional items to sell, including milk and groceries. In the future, she would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy additional items to sell including milk and groceries.

loans.name: Colleta

texts.en:
Colleta is 28 years old, married to Grace and has two children. She lives in Migori, Kenya.

Colleta has a telephone bureau that she runs and has applied for her first loan from KADET LTD to enable her to buy calling cards and other telephone accessories. The profits made will be used to pay school fees for her children.

She hopes to open another telephone bureau in the future.

loans.use: to buy calling cards and other telephone accessories.

loans.name: Flora

texts.en:
Flora runs a sari-sari store business and sells snack foods, cooking oil and spices. Flora is married and blessed with seven children. Flora’s husband is a farmer, planting rice and vegetables. Flora only finished her elementary level of education even though she wanted to enter college, because her parents had no capacity to send her to school. This reason pushes her to work hard to be able to send her children to school until college. She wants her children to finish their education because she doesn't want them to be like her. She wants them to have a better future someday. Flora has two children in college and prays that they will finish their studies. 

Flora wishes to expand her business and earn a higher income to further sustain her children's needs in school. She wants to borrow a loan for PHP 20,000 to buy additional goods to sell in their village like drinks, bread, eggs and coffee.

loans.use: to buy additional goods to sell in their village like drinks, bread, eggs and coffee.

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace is a hardworking business woman. She is 32 and married.

For the last two years, she has been operating a motorbike transport business to earn a living. She also does tailoring to supplement her income.  She has retained her business because of her hard work and determination.

In the next 5 years, she wants to buy a plot of land. She is requesting a loan of 20,000 Kenyan shillings to buy a sewing machine for her tailoring business.

loans.use: to buy a sewing machine

loans.name: Jonas

texts.es: El sr. Jonás vive en  la zona del plan 3000 en casa familiar el vive al lado de su esposa  y su hijo. El se dedica al transporte publico con su propio vehículo, también tiene una venta de repuestos de automóviles en su casa, el tiene 4 años de experiencia en el transporte publico. El crédito que esta solicitando es para la compra de una compresora de aire ya que también esta abriendo un taller mecánico. El sr. Jonás es un hombre trabajador, que con mucho esfuerzo se compro un vehículo para trabajar de noche y de día atiende su venta de repuestos con el apoyo de su esposa, con el dinero del crédito comprara una compresora de aire, es un apersona muy trabajadora con deseos de seguir adelante para mejorar la calidad de vida de el y de toda su familia.
texts.en:
Señor Jonas lives in the Plan 3000 neighborhood in the family home with his wife and his son. He makes his living in public transportation, using his own vehicle. He also sells spare auto parts in his home. He has 4 years of experience in public transportation.

The loan that he is requesting is for the purchase of an air compressor, as he is also opening a mechanic shop. Señor Jonas is a hardworking man who, through much effort, purchased a car so that he could work at night. During the day, he handles his spare parts sales with the support of his wife. He will purchase an air compressor with the money from the loan. He is a very hardworking person with desires to succeed in order to improve the quality of life for himself and for his whole family.

loans.use: to purchase an air compressor.

loans.name: David

texts.en:
David is 31 years old. He is married to Ann and together they have two children. He sells sandals. He has been in the business for the past 12 years. He gets a monthly income of 20,000 Kenyan shillings (KES) from the business.

This is his first loan with KADET LTD. He will use the loan amount to purchase sandals to add more stock for his business. 

He will use anticipated profits to educate his children. He hopes to have a stable business and to open an enclosed stall.

loans.use: to purchase sandals.

loans.name: Baronesa Bionet

texts.es:
En la ciudadela El Progreso de la ciudad de Portoviejo se reúne cada quince días el Banco Comunal Girasoles, esta es una zona urbano marginal muy poblada en esta ciudad, se la conoce como el sector de la cárcel ya que en esta zona queda la cárcel de mujeres de Portoviejo.

En este lugar conocimos a la señora Baronesa. Tiene 63 años de edad, está soltera pero de una relación que tuvo hace muchos años tuvo tres hijos los mismos que ya  son mayores de edad, el menor de ellos aun vive con ella.

Ella para ganarse el sustento diario desde hace varios años tiene una pequeña panadería donde además de pan fabrica y vende deliciosos pasteles. Trabaja todos los días desde las  5h00 en el horneando el pan el mismo que desde el dia anterior deja preparado para el dia siguiente, vende en su pequeño local y también entrega a una fundación todos los fines de semana.

Este crédito es para comprar harina, mantequilla, huevos, levadura y otros productos necesarios para la fabricación del pan y sus pasteles. Es socia fundadora del Banco Comunal y le gusta porque los créditos le ayudan a mejorar su  negocio.
 
Su sueño es formar una microempresa de fabricación de pasteles.
texts.en:
Every two weeks the 'Girasoles' (Sunflowers) community bank meets in El Progreso neighborhood, in the city of Portoviejo.  This is a very densely populated, poor, urban area of the city.  It is known as 'Sector de la Cárcel' (Prison Sector) because it is home to Portoviejo's women's prison.

Here we meet Baronesa.  She is 63 years old and single but has three children from a relationship that she had many years ago.  Her children are grown up but her youngest still lives with her.

In order to earn a living, Baronesa has been running a small bakery for several years.  As well as making bread, she also makes and sells delicious cakes.  She works every day, from 5.00am, baking bread which she prepares the day before.  She sells from her small premises and also delivers to an establishment every weekend.

Baronesa will use this loan to buy flour, butter, eggs, yeast and other products she needs for making bread and cakes.  She is a founding member of her community bank and she likes it because the loans help her to improve her business.  Her dream is to set up a cake-making micro business.

loans.use: to buy flour, butter, eggs, yeast, etc.

loans.name: Mathews

texts.en:
Mathews lives in the Mombasa area in the coastal province of Kenya. Matthews is married and has five children who are all in school. He has run a transport van ferrying clients’ cargo and goods in the area for one year. His business has offered employment to three other people.

Mathews, who is also employed elsewhere, joined Milango early this year after being invited by a friend. He has applied for a loan of KES 40,000 to help him repair his van. This will enable him to continue serving his clients. He desires to apply for higher loan amounts in future and to purchase other trucks.

loans.use: To repair his van.

loans.name: Chultem

texts.en:
Chultem is 47 years old and lives with his wife and three children in a ger (Mongolian yurt) in Arhangai Province, Mongolia. His wife is unemployed, his elder child graduated from college and is employed, and his middle daughter university student and the youngest attends a secondary school. 

He started his taxi service business in 1999 using his own car. Also, he is a part time security guard in a mining company. Now that his car is old, he is losing a lot of customers to the newer cars. He is a sharp and diligent man who says, "I don't like to waste time and opportunity. I have one child who is in college and she needs my support now." 

He is requesting 2,500,000 MNT to buy new fence for his family.

loans.use: To buy new fence for his family

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is a 30-year-old married woman with three children between the ages of 2 and 8 years; two of them are in school. She has had a business of selling charcoal in Kator, South Sudan, for four years.

Mary requested this loan through BRAC South Sudan to purchase charcoal. She will use her extra income from this loan to build a house in the future.

loans.use: to purchase charcoal for sale.

loans.name: Jose Luis

texts.es:
José Luis tiene 33 años de edad vive en unión libre tiene 4 hijos, vive con la esposa y con los hijos de 10, 9, 7 y 2 años de edad en el Cantón Ventanas Provincia de los Ríos.

Es integrante de la VRC LAS PALMAS, se encuentra ubicada en el Recinto campo Alegre, Pertenece al Cantón Bab se dedican a labores Agrícolas.

José se dedica a la agricultura a la siembra de maíz, arroz hace 20 años.  Las compras y las ventas lo realiza en Ventanas.

Solicita el crédito para comprar semillas y abonos agrícolas.

Con la ayuda del crédito podrá comprar los insumos sin ningún tipo de problema. El sueño es poder comprase una casa. No se le ha presentado ningún tipo de problema. En los tiempos libres le gusta hacer deporte.
texts.en:
José Luis is 33 years old, in a common law relationship and has four children.  He lives with his wife and children who are 10, 9, 7 and 2 years old in Ventanas Canton, Los Ríos Province.

The members of the “Las Palmas” communal bank are located in Recinto Campo Alegre belonging to Bab Canton; they are farmers.  José is a farmer who has been growing rice and corn for 20 years.  His purchases and his sales take place in Ventanas.

He is asking for the loan to buy seeds and agricultural manure.  With help from the loan he will be able to buy supplies problem-free.  His dream is to be able to buy a tractor.  He has had no type of problem and in his free time he enjoys playing sports.

loans.use: to buy seeds and manure.

loans.name: Delgermaa

texts.en:
Mrs. Delgermaa, 27 studies Korean and has the translation business. She lives with her husband and her daughter in the slum district of Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. Delgermaa usually makes the interpretation by USD 5-7 in an hour and sometimes her job line is cut during many days.  She has been doing her business for 4 years. Also she studies in the advanced level course of Korean. 
She requested a loan to purchase the new notebook for her translation job. Because the notebook is a main works tool of her business and she uses it for her translation jobs and her studies. Her old previous notebook had damaged 2 weeks ago. During the past 2 weeks her business has been stopped among. Therefore she needs to purchase the new one. The loan she is taking will be dedicated to purchase the notebook for her studying of Korean. It is absolutely important to her language studying and her future business career.

loans.use: To purchase the notebook for her studying of Korean

loans.name: Chou

texts.en: Chou, 46, is married and resides in Kampong Chnang Province. Chou is a farmer, and her husband is a fisherman. Chou is requesting a loan of US $1000 to purchase a mechanical plow for her husband to transport firewood and charcoal to sell. In the future, Chou would like to use any additional income to run a grocery store in front of her house. This will be her first loan from KREDIT, a longstanding Kiva partner.

loans.use: to purchase a mechanical plow to transport firewood and charcoal to sell

loans.name: Leslie

texts.en:
Leslie is married with two children. Leslie is 24 years-old, and lives in Liposong Ozamis City, Philippines.

He operates a service-based business, providing transportation services to the local community members to earn a living. He has been doing this for five years, and every month he earns PHP 2,000.00 from this work. He has requested a loan of PHP 8,000.00 to repair his existing vehicle to provide a better service.

In 2010, Leslie joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his business and living situation. In the future, Leslie hopes for his children to finish their studies, and to gain double the income out of his business.

loans.use: to repair existing vehicle for better service.

loans.name: Mercedes Yanira

texts.es:
Mercedes es una madre soltera muy luchadora, tiene que cuidar de su hijo de 6 años de edad, para obtener ingresos ella administra  sola una tienda de productos de la canasta básica, su horario de trabajo es de seis de la mañana a cuatro de la tarde, este negocio es su medio de subsistencia familiar.
Para ofrecer a sus clientes un inventario más surtido necesita de un crédito que utilizara para comprar boquitas, dulces, bebidas, huevos, productos enlatados, etc.,  estos productos le ayudaran a disminuir las necesidades de sus clientes, espera recuperar la inversión con mejores ganancias y así cancelar a tiempo las cuotas de la deuda.
Sus ilusiones son ampliar su negocio mucho más, comprar un vehículo para realizar mejor sus actividades y salir de paseo con su hijo.

loans.use: comprar boquitas, dulces, bebidas, huevos, productos enlatados, etc.,  estos productos le ayudaran a disminuir las necesidades de sus clientes

loans.name: Juana

texts.en:
Four years ago Juana started selling used clothing from her home, following the necessity for an income that would purchase school supplies and pay the tuition of her two children, that with her husband's salary would not be possible. First she asked her family for coothes that she could use to sell, something that later evolved into purchasing package lots of clothes. Thanks to the support of her family, Juana still manages her business, always motivated by the enormous wish to provide her children with a better quality of life and future, something that she could only give them through an education, an education she did not have.

Now she needs to purchase two package lots of clothes, as she has run out of merchandise to sell. She also wants to start selling in the local markets to increase her earnings. For all of this she is requesting a loan of $200 that she plans to repay in a term of 3 months. You can become an important part of the efforts of Juana and her family. Do not wait, the decision is in your hands. She will sincerely thank you.

Translated from Spanish by Erika Lindig, Kiva Volunteer.

Hace 4 años Juana comenzó a vender ropa usada en su domicilio, tras la necesidad de contar con ingresos que le permitieran pagar los útiles escolares y colegiaturas de sus dos hijos, pues con el sueldo de su esposo esto era imposible. Primero pidió a sus familiares ropa que la no les sirviera para comenzar a vender, luego de un tiempo comenzó a comprar pacas de ropa. Gracias al apoyo de su familia, Juana continua con su proyecto, siempre impulsada por el enorme deseo de brindarles a sus hijos una mejor calidad de vida futura y esto sólo puede logarlo proporcionandoles la educación que ella no tuvo.

Ahora ella necesita comprar dos pacas de ropa, pues ya no tiene mercancía que ofrecer, además que comenzará a vender en los mercados rodantes para aumentar sus ingresos. Para esto esta solicitando un crédito de $ 200 DLLS, mismos que planea regresar en un plazo de 3 mese. Tu puedes convertirte en parte importante de los logros de Juana y su familia, no lo dudes más, la decisión esta en sus manos, ella te lo va a agradece sinceramente.

loans.use: purchase merchandise

loans.name: Esteban

texts.en:
Despite Esteban's age, he still works the lands that were given to him by his father. He is a rice farmer in Baba, Ecuador where he was born and raised. He has had two children, both of whom are grown up and independent. He lives on his farm with his wife and together they make ends meet through rice production. He hopes he can invest the loan by acquiring fertilizers that will help his crops grow better.

Communal Banking in Baba

This borrower is part of the newest and largest Communal Bank in the recently developed Mifex Rural Finance Program. All of the members of the Centro Agricola de Baba Communal Bank are part of an Association of Rice Farmers in the county of Baba in rural Ecuador. Their association works cooperatively to cultivate rice and commercialize the product after it has grown. As an association, Centro Agricola helps the farmers by providing access to machinery and training services. The farmers from Centro Agricola have received special instruction on financial responsibility and accounting from Codemicro, an organization that specializes in training programs geared towards the rural sector.

The members of Centro Agricola de Baba will use the micro-loans to prepare their lands and cultivate rice on their farms. Because they form part of a communal bank, they are all each others' guarantors for the loan. This means that if for some reason one person in the group cannot fully repay the loan, the other borrowers and the Centro Agricola de Baba Association are responsible for the amount in default. The members of the bank also participate in a program designed to teach and encourage savings among the group. Promoting savings is often forgotten in many micro-finance programs, but Mifex believes that is imperative for the communities we works with to have capital reserved for future investments or unexpected difficulties.

Below is more information about Santa Lucia compiled by Luis Crespo and Robert Edgar of the Mifex team when evaluating the potential of the sector for the Rural Finance Program.

Economy of Baba

The people of Baba have been organized since the days of Gran Colombia when Ecuador was yet to be a country. The area has always been popular because of the extremely productive lands that gave way to cultivation of cacao for decades. Now Baba is a county in the province of Los Rios in the coastal region of Ecuador. For most of the latter part of the 20th Century it was a cacao and banana-producing sector. Most of the surrounding areas of Baba in Los Rios are owned by large multinational companies such as Dole, but Baba is a sector characterized by small and informal farms.

Rice production has now turned into the main economic activity of the sector as about 80% of the people are rice farmers. Cacao is still very popular in the area, but because of the long cultivation cycle people prefer to invest in rice. The lands in Baba are very fertile though, and most farmers in the sector often grow other crops, such as plantains and soybeans as secondary sources of income. Many farmers also keep livestock as emergency sources of food and income, commonly resorting to selling a chicken or pig if they are in need of cash.

Rice Farming in Santa Lucia

Most of the people in the Baba area are small farmers. They produce about 80 sacks of rice per hectare of land. In order to farm they first must prepare the lands by removing weeds, plowing and leveling the lands. This is the most difficult part for the farmers in Baba, who often lack the necessary machinery to properly plow the lands for rice production. After appropriately preparing the lands, the farmers fill an area with water to form what is known as a paddy field, because rice is a very water-intensive crop. The rice seeds are either dispersed freely (the process is known as boleo in Spanish) or hand sowed. Once the rice has grown, most farmers rent machinery that helps them gather their production.

Access to Credit

One of the biggest struggles in the area has been the lack of credit due to the absence of any type of financial institution. Because people do not count on formal financial finance, they have turned to loan sharks for financing. They have been affected by expensive lines of credit that exceed 100% interest a year and can be as expensive as 240%. Intermediaries also exploit the farmers because of their outstanding debt. Farmers also lack skills and knowledge to commercialize their products and pay fair prices for their crops.

Risks

The largest risk in the sector is due to absence of watering systems. Although Baba is in the province “Los Rios” (the rivers) there is severe problem with access to water. The lack of infrastructure in the sector does not allow the small farmers to benefit from the presence of the many rivers in the area. If the winter season is too dry, it is likely that the lands will not be sufficiently fertile for rice production in the summer. On the other hand, if there is too much rain, there are not any drainage systems to prevent flooding and the crops are often ruined. Generally speaking though, Baba is a very productive sector where the lands yield all types of crops including rice, cacao, corn, watermelons, plantains, and soybeans.

Loan Use

The loans in this sector will mostly be used to buy soil, seeds, fertilizer and insecticides. Many clients will use the capital towards renting machinery and equipment necessary to effectively work and prepare the fields. Clients also typically use a part of the loan to buy livestock in order to raise and have as reserves. The loan repayment schedule is different from the typical micro-entrepreneur because farmers see the profits from their investments 5 or 6 months after making their initial expenditures. Mifex asks our rural clients only to pay 50% of the capital in the first 6 months of the loan. The rest of the debt must be paid in the seventh and final month.

loans.use: Rice farming

loans.name: Sohor Lorena

texts.en:
My name is Sohor C. and I sell used clothes. I have had my business for a year. This business is very good because clothes sell fast due to their low sale prices. I need more inventory in order to have more sales because this month is good for sales. With the earnings I make I plan to feed my daughter and pay for her studies.

Translated from Spanish by Yael Schwartzman, Kiva Volunteer.

Mi nombre es Sohor C. me dedico a la venta de ropa usada, tengo mi negocio hace 1 año, este negocio es muy bueno proque la ropa se vende rapido ya que tiene precios bajos de venta, en estos momentos necesito mas inventario para tener mas ventas porque este mes es muy bueno para las ventas, con las ganancias que obtenga poder alimentar mi hija y pagarle sus estudios.

loans.use: Purchase used clothes

loans.name: Marcela

texts.es:
Señora Marcela lives in her own home with her husband and their children on the street "Huallparrimachi" in the zone of "Tembladerani" in the city of La Paz. Her husband works as a bricklayer receiving a daily income. She sells food on the corner of Avenue 20, which provides food for their family, and with the income from her husband they are renovating their home.

The loan that they are requesting is for purchasing materials like stucco, cement, bricks, etc, and continue the renovation for a better life. Their previous history with IMPRO qualifies them as a good client and they can receive a new loan.

Translated from Spanish by Jay Osborne, Kiva volunteer

La señora Marcela vive en casa propia con su esposo y sus hijos en la calle Huallparrimachi de la zona de Tembladerani de la Ciudad de La Paz; el esposo trabaja como albañil percibiendo un ingreso por jornal, ella vende comida en la esquina de la av. 20 de octubre, con lo cual cubre la alimentación de su familia, pero con los ingresos del esposo están refaccionando su vivienda.

El crédito que solicita es para comprar material, como ser estuco, cemento, ladrillos, etc. y continuar con la refacción para poder vivir mejor. Su antecedente histórico con Impro la califica como muy buen cliente y puede acceder a un nuevo crédito.

loans.use: Renovate their home

loans.name: María Luz

texts.en: María is a 34 years old woman with a very intelligent 10 year old daughter.  The girl is going to school in the township. She lives with her husband who works in her community.  She owns a little grocery store where she sells basic foodstuffs like rice, sugar, potatoes, peas, juice, water and other goods.  The "local" (a commercial space) where she runs her business is in a very disagreeable condition.  She is requesting a loan to remedy that situation.  She plans to renovate the small local and outfit the space in order to make goods visible to the public.  She would like to have her ‘new’ local ready for the holiday season.  María thinks that remodeling the local is a step to progress for her business.

loans.use: To renovate her small local store and outfit the space to make the goods visible to the clients.

loans.name: Savuth

texts.en:
Mr. Van Savuth got married in 1982 and has 6 children: five sons and one daughter. His father taught him construction skills and he started his own business in 1987. He is a construction contractor and his wife stays at home to take care of their children. One of his son works as a construction worker with him and his daughter works in a garment factory while the other sons are in school. Savuth and his wife finished just primary school.

Mr Van has borrowed money from MAXIMA four times already. He is now requesting a $1,000 loan to purchase construction materials for his business.

loans.use: Purchase construction materials

loans.name: Mariquita

texts.es:
Mariquita lives in the region of San Martin, province and districs of Lamas, which belongs to Banco Comunal Mujeres del 2000. She makes and sells breads and sweets in her own bakery which is located in her own house. Her home is located in the lower section of Lamas city, via Marcos Mori.

With the expertise of her husband as breadmaker they decided to install their own bread machine over 20 years ago, getting started with a small capital and hand-shaping the breads that they baked. Slowly but surely they were able to get the people's approval and at the same time get loans necessary to purchase a "sobadora" (this is a machine that allows them to bake more breads on a daily basis). To this date, production has increased and they work on individual orders, especially during holidays such as Christmas, New Year's, religious holidays, and anniversary of the city.

With the loan requsted, which they plan on paying back within 6 months, they will buy pans to be able to shape their breads, flour, sugar in bags, confectioners flowers, lots of eggs, other ingredients such as sugar, lard boxed milk, and special items for special orders to fullfill the public and private sector.

Translated from Spanish by Maria Peterson, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Mariquita vive en la región de San Martín, provincia y distrito de Lamas, pertenece al Banco Comunal Mujeres del 2000. Se dedica a la elaboración y venta de panes y dulces en una propia panadería que se encuentra instalada en su propia casa ubicada en la parte baja de la ciudad de Lamas, pasaje Marcos Mori s/n. Contando con la experiencia de su esposo como panificador deciden instalar su propia panadería hace mas de 20 años, iniciándose con un pequeño capital y un pequeño horno elaborando los panes en forma manual. Poco a poco fueron ganando la preferencia del publicó y con el ingreso al banco comunal que le permite obtener prestamos y comprar una sobadora (máquina que les permite elaborar mayor cantidad de panes por día). A la fecha su producción ha aumentado y trabajan con pedidos sobre todo en fechas festivas como Navidad, año nuevo, fiestas religiosas y aniversario de la ciudad. Con el préstamo de S/. 2,500.00, el cual pagará en 6 meses, comprará los moldes para panteones en cientos, harina y azúcar en sacos, frutas confitadas y pasas en kilos, huevos al por mayor, otros ingredientes como mantequilla, manteca en kilos, leche en cajas y esencias especiales para cubrir los pedidos de instituciones publicas y privadas. Mariquita junto a su esposo e hijos, quienes también ayudan en el negocio, sueñan con una mezcladora y una cortadora de panes y convertir la actual sobadora manual en eléctrica y así salir adelante y alcanzar las metas proyectadas.

loans.use: Purchase of containers and consumables (flour, sugar, fruits, raisins, etc.)

loans.name: Madeleyne Yanina

texts.es:
Ms. Madeleyne Yanina is 37 years old. She is a woman who works to support her 3 children who still depend on her. She only did the first graD. of elementary school and she lives in the district of Mache, Province of Otuzco, department of La Libertad. She buys curd (quesillo) from different hamlets in the district of Mache, then she sell it in the city of Trujillo. She also buys small animals as guinea pigs, hens and pigs to fatten and then sell them. She started by selling candies and sodas at her house and then she started the business of the selling curd. The first loan of $100 that she obtained from the communal bank "Women of Work", she bought candies and sodas. With the loan of $725 that she will repay in 4 months, she plans to buy a bull that will serve her help to plough the land where she has her crops and with what she has left she will buy 2 small rams. Madeleyne’s wish is to have a big number of cows to use their milk to prepare milk products.

Translated from Spanish by Ana Gabriela Clark, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Madeleyne Yanina tiene 37 años D. edad, es una mujer que trabaja para sacar adelante a sus 3 hijos que aún dependen D. ella. Estudió sólo el primer grado D. primaria y vive en el distrito D. Mache, Provincia D. Otuzco, departamento D. La Libertad. Ella compra cuajada (quesillo) por diferentes caseríos del distrito D. Mache para luego venderlos en la ciudad D. Trujillo, también compra animales menores como cuyes, gallinas y cerdos para engordarlos y luego venderlos. Empezó vendiendo golosinas y gaseosas en su casa y después se inició en el negocio D. la venta D. cuajada. El primer préstamo que recibió en su banco comunal “Mujeres D. Trabajo” fue D. S/. 300.00 y con este dinero compró golosinas y gaseosas. Con el préstamo D. S/. 2,100.00, el cual pagará en 4 meses, comprará un toro que le servirá D. ayuda para arar la tierra donD. tiene sus sembríos y con lo que le queda comprará 2 carneros pequeños. El sueño D. Madeleyne es tener un gran número D. vacas para aprovechar su leche y elaborar productos lácteos.

loans.use: Buy a bull and rams.

loans.name: Yun

texts.en:
Mrs. Yun B., 43, and her husband, Moul Klat, have been married since 1990. They have three sons. Their oldest son sells flowers and other two are studying in the local school. The family lives along the Tonle Basac River, a tributary of the nearby Mekong approximately fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Mrs. B. has been growing and selling jasmine flowers since 2000. Her husband is a construction worker and a farmer. Both husband and wife hope that their businesses will be able to support the family and enable their children to continue their studies. She is requesting her fourth loan in the amount of $900. She will use this money to purchase a motorbike to travel to Phnom Penh.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike

loans.name: Huyen

texts.en:
Huyen, 29, and her husband Thanh, 41, are originally from a town near Hanoi in the north of Vietnam. They moved to Tanh Linh in hopes of being abL. to make a better living. Finding work was initially very difficult, so they asked for a loan in order to get started. The lender they received the loan from charged an exorbitant interest rate, which left them stuck in poverty.

Huyen runs a small grocery store in the front of their home and Thanh works as a day laborer. Huyen is abL. to earn between 10-15,000 VND (US$ 0.62-$ 0.94) per day. Thanh earns about 30,000 VND per day (about $1.85 US), but he is not always abL. to find work. With the loan from Mekong Plus and Kiva, they can save more of their money without worrying about interest payments. They are trying to raise two children, Han T. Tuyet Loan and Han Minh Cong, aged 8 and 4 respectively. They received loan from Kiva on September 2007 and paid it back on time after four months. She hopes to continue with Kiva again to help her business grow.

loans.use: To expand grocery store

loans.name: Abdul Samat

texts.en: Abdul Samat lives in district 7 of Kabul, Afghanistan. He is married. He has a clothing shop where he works. He has good experience. He already took his first cycle loan and was able to expand his business. Now he has requested his second cycle individual loan to enlarge his shop further to attract more customers and make a good monthly income to help his family. He is very happy to be requesting his second cycle loan.

loans.use: To enlarge his small clothing shop

loans.name: Nelva Jesus

texts.en:
Nelva Jesus V. D. L. is a business woman in the town of Mache, high in the sierras (mountain range) of the La Libertad region of Peru. Nelva owns a home in which she has a general store and a small eatery, and she rents out rooms to travelers. The meals she serves for lunch are very popular among the population. She has been a business woman for many years and has many loyal customers.

Nelva is 57 years old, a widow, and a has 7 children. Her children have all moved away from home so she lives alone. Without her businesses, she wouldn’t be able to survive, because she has no one to rely on.

A member of the Mujeres D. Mache community bank, Nelva is requesting a loan of s/800 ($300 USD) that she will repay over 4 months. She will use the loan to restock her store and buy ingredients to prepare her meals.

loans.use: To restock her store and buy ingredients to prepare her meals

loans.name: Eufemia

texts.es:
Eufemia started her business because her husband’s earnings were not enough to cover their living expenses. She worked in a “maquiladora” (factory) but was not earning a full salary, which made it very difficult to financially meet the needs of her three small children. This is how she came to decide to start selling clothing, initially offering her goods to relatives. She now has built a good customer base.

She seeks a loan of $400USD to be repaid over six months. The loan would be used to purchase merchandise so she can, in turn, increase her sales. With your support, she will be able to reach her goal.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn, Kiva Volunteer.

Eufemia empezo su negocio porque no completaba con el dinero que percibia su esposo para solventar los gastos del hogar. Ella trabajaba en una maquiladora, pero no estaba percibiendo su salario completo, por lo que le era muy dificil solventar los gastos de sus 3 pequeños hijos. Fue asi que decidio vender ropa, empezo ofreciendola a sus familiares, y actualmente tiene una buena cartera de clientes.

Ella necesita un prestamo por US $400 que pagara en 6 meses para comprar mercancia y asi poder incrementar sus ventas. Con tu apoyo podra lograrlo.

loans.use: Purchase merchandise.

loans.name: Vumilia

texts.en:
Mambo from Mbeya, Tanzania! This is 30 year-old Vumilia M.. She is married and has three children ages seven, three, and one. In 2005 Vumilia established her clothes business. Working 6 days a week and five to eight hours a day, she earns about US $100 every month from this business. Vumilia requires a loan in order to buy more clothes in bulk. In the future, Vumilia plans to expand her business. She thanks you for your support.

SELFINA is engaged in economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through leasing and leaseback facility as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed not-creditworthy by financial institutions as they lack tangible collateral assets. This leads to poor financial support hence poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes.

SELFINA buys and leases equipment to women. Where a client needs working capital SELFINA buys equipment from said client, extending a loan to her, then leasing back the same equipment – a process called a sale and leaseback arrangement

loans.use: To buy more clothes in bulk.

loans.name: Sruy

texts.en: This is the second time for Mrs. Sruy K. to take a loan to do her business activity. She and her husband, Mr. Phi Phall, are laborers in the village of Pouthi Reamea in Kandal Province. Aside from this business, Mrs. Sruy K. is a cow breeder. Since her second business is going well, she wants to expand it, so she decided to ask for a loan to buy two more cows which cost KHR 1,000,000 ($250) each for breeding. Mrs. Sruy K. has three children, one of whom is employed in a garment factory, while another one is attending junior high school. The youngest one is too young to work or study. Her husband is shown on the left of the photo.

loans.use: To buy two more cows for breeding.

loans.name: Vichai

texts.en:
Mr. Vichai K. and his wife, Mrs. Sokly Chin, live in a small village off National Road Two, about twenty kilometers south of Phnom Penh.  They were married in 2004 and have one son. 

Mr. Vichai has been a taxi driver for many years, while his wife is a garment factory worker. He also works cutting grass to sell for cow feed. He travels to a nearby village by motorbike to cut the grass, and sells it along National Road Two. Now it is the rainy season, so he gathers much more grass.  He needs to buy a trailer to carry the extra grass. Therefore, he is requesting a loan of US$300 to purchase a trailer to carry grass to sell.

loans.use: To purchase a trailer to carry grass to sell.

loans.name: Esmelda Dalila

texts.es: Inició su pequeño negocio vendiendo refrescos, gaseosas y panes,  lo que le permitió conocer a todos sus vecinos y a solicitud de ellos empezó a introducir pequeñas cantidades de productos básicos del hogar, el negocio lo tenía dentro de su casa  inicialmente y con el apoyo de su esposo ha logrado construir un anexo a la casa y de esta manera montar su pequeña pulpería, en la actualidad, el préstamo de ADIM lo pretende invertir en la compra de productos lácteos. Su mayor propósito es tener una pulpería grande en su casa, la cual dice que solo logrará con la ayuda que ADIM le pueda brindar a través del acceso al crédito.
texts.en:
She began her small business selling soft drinks and breads, which allowed her to meet her neighbors and to serve them by beginning to introduce small quantities of basic products for the house. She had the business inside her house to begin, and with the help of her spouse she was able to construct an annex to the house and in this way begin her own grocery shop. At the moment, the loan from ADIM would be invested in the purchase of milk products. Her big goal is to have a big shop in her home, which she says that she can only achieve with the help that ADIM could bring her through the access to credit.

Translated from Spanish by Jessica Kaminsky, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working Capital

loans.name: Chan

texts.en:
Mrs. Chan C., 45, and her husband, Mr. Phat Krouch, live in a small village across the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh. They were marred in 1984 and have two children; one son and one daughter. Their daughter is married and lives outside the family home and their son studies in local school. 

Chan has been a silk weaver for twenty-eight years, a skill she learned from her sister. Her husband has been a silk weaver for over ten years, a skill he learned from Chan. They sell their finished products to the middle man in the village, who then takes it to sell in Phnom Penh.    

Chan is requesting a loan of $500 to purchase silk material for weaving.

loans.use: To purchase silk material for weaving.

loans.name: Saodat

texts.en: S. Saodat is 39 years old and lives in Khujand. She operates a clothing trade outlet at the local bazar, and boasts a wide variety of clothing. She has built a loyal network of repeat customers. S. Saodat became first joined the local bank in 2007 and has been a model client. She repays her loans on time, and never has problems with loan procedure.  Now mrs. S. Saodat is applying for a KIVA business support loan of 4000 STJ for 3 months to increase volume of imports of seasonal winter wear.

loans.use: importing winter clothing

loans.name: Phat

texts.en:
Mr. Phat V. is a villager born in 1943. He now lives in Toek Nim village in Kandal province. He is a farmer who cultivates both rice and vegetable. His wife, Mrs. In Nai, helps him in the plantation. They have two children who are both employed in a garment factory.

Although they try to work hard, they still earn insufficient income and live in an old house in poor conditions. In order to improve these, Mr. Phat V. decided to ask for a loan to add to his savings to build a new house for the family. His wife is also presented with him in the picture.

loans.use: To add to his savings to build a new house for the family.

loans.name: Nkokonjeru-Kiiza Halima Group

texts.en:
Halima K. (right) is 37 years old. She is a single mother of 6 children, of whom 3 are in school. For a period of 10 years now, Halima has been selling fruit (sugarcane, jack fruit, mangoes, oranges, etc) and vegetables (cabbages, kale, cowpeas, etc.) Rehema needs a loan to enable her to make advance payments for sugarcane and also purchase sacks of charcoal to add on to her line of businesses.

From her sales, she earns an approximate profit of 18%. The income from the business has kept her family going. However, Halima's dream is to run a general retail shop within her locality. She also hopes to have her children study up to higher institutions (universities and colleges).

loans.use: Advance payment for sugarcane and purchasing sacks of charcoal as a new business

loans.name: Mao

texts.en: Mao D., 46, is married and lives with her husband and four of her children in the Kampong Chhnang province.  Since 2006, she has been selling food and rice in the market to earn a living, and is able to make around US$4 every day. Her husband earns about US$5 working as a journalist. Two of their children are students and two are employed as workers in a Hotel in Siem Reap province. As rice selling is making less profit, Mrs. Mao D. is asking for a loan to create a new business selling children shoes. She expects the switch will increase her profits to support her family.

loans.use: To invest in a new  business - selling children's shoes

loans.name: Carlos Javier

texts.es:
Carlos  inició el negocio despues de  emigrar de Tampico, y de llegar al que es ahora su domicilio pues no había tiendas cercanas y su esposa y el decidieron abrir uns toenda y a la fecha les ha fructificado mucho.

Comenzó el negocio en Septiembre del 2006 vendiendo refrescos y un poco de abarrotes, pero conforme paso el tiempo los proveedores se acercaron a su tienda y fue asi como metieron a la venta papas fritas, galletas y demás, cosas que la gente buscaba y pues a la fecha han podido responderles.

les ha ido muy bien, en casi tres años del negocio las ventas cada vez son mejores, la gente los busca mas porque sabe que tienen lo que necesitan a muy buen precio, y eso los hace ser los favoritos en la colonia.


El neecsita un prestamo por $3000 que pagara en 6 catorcenas para comprar una vitrina y ahí poder tener artículos de papelería, ya que eso nos hace falta y los estudiantes buscan mucho, por lo que ahora quiere ampliar su negocio dando este servicio tambien.
texts.en:
Carlos started his business after emigrating from Tampico. He found that there weren't any nearby stores by his house so he and his wife decided to open a store and to this date it has been fruitful to them. He began the business in September 2006 selling refreshments and some groceries, but as time went on, suppliers approached the store and that is how they ended up selling potato chips, cookies and more things people wanted. To this date the store has been able to respond to those needs. So far they have done very well. In almost three years of business, sales have increased; people seek them more because they know they have what they need at an affordable price, and that makes them the favorites in the neighborhood. He needs a loan for $3000 that he will pay in 6 two-week installments so he can buy a display case to show office supplies, since that is what they need and students seek a lot. He wants to expand his business giving this service as well.

Translated from Spanish by Jonathan Bradshaw, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of a display case

loans.name: Tindelo

texts.en:
Tindelo M. is currently in the business of selling at a hotel and is requesting a loan to buy chairs and tables for the hotel. Tindelo is 40 years old and is married with a husband who is a businessman. Tindelo has 6 children all of whom go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house for her family.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To buy chairs and tables for the hotel

loans.name: Eufemia

texts.es:
La señora Eufemia C. D. R. tiene 66 años vive en Chongoyape, distrito D. Paijan, provincia D. Ascope, departamento D. La Libertad, Perú.
Ella estudió hasta 1er grado D. primaria, abandono los estudios debido a que sus padres no tenían los medios económicos para seguir apoyándola, tiene 10 hijos y ninguno depenD. económicamente D. ella.
Eufemia se dedica a la venta D. condimentos, inicio su negocio con la venta D. leche  y verduras hace 20 años en Paijan y luego se traslado al mercado D.  CasagranD. donD. se dedico a la venta D. leche y verduras, con las ganancias obtenidas amplio su negocio a la venta D. condimentos hace 2 años, negocio que le es rentable y que desarrolla actualmente en el mercado modelo D. CasagranD.. 
Con el primer crédito D. 300 soles que recibió D. su banco comunal “Manos Unidas”, lo invirtió en la compra D. verduras. 
Con el crédito D. 2000 soles, que será cancelado en  6 meses, lo invertirá en la  compra D. todo tipo D. condimentos para la venta.
Eufemia sueña con comprarse un molino eléctrico y le gustaría conocer argentina.
Ella pertenece al club D. madres D. su sector.
texts.en:
Señora Eufemia C. D. R. is 66 and lives in Chongoyape in the district of Paijan, in the province of Ascope, in the department of La Libertad, Perú. She studied through first graD. and stopped going to school because her parents didn't have the economic means to support her education anymore. She has 10 children, none of whom depend on her financially. Eufemia sells condiments. She started her business 20 years ago by selling milk and vegetables in Paijan. She then moved to a market in CasagranD. to sell condiments 2 years ago. Her business is profitable and she currently has it in the model market in CasagranD.. With her first loan of 300 PEN that she received from her communal bank, "Manos Unidas" (United Hands), she invested in the purchase of vegetables. With this credit of 2000 PEN, which will be repaid in 6 months, she will invest in the purchase of all kinds of condiments to sell. Eufemia dreams about buying an electric mill and would like to go to Argentina. She belongs to the mother's club in her area.

Translated from Spanish by Tanya Harper, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: She will purchase all kinds of condiments for food

loans.name: Norovsambuu

texts.en: Y. Norovsambuu lives with her husband and son in the Bayanzurh district of Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. Her son goes a local kindergarten. Y. has a small retail business selling clothing at the "Bombogor" shopping mall, one of the more popular shopping malls in the city. Y. started her clothing business in 2007 when she learned that there was a high demand for cheap, quality clothing from Beijing, China. She often travels to Beijing, China to purchase non-brand, quality clothing for women and men at bargain prices. She is very fashionable and knows well what kind of trendy clothing Ulaanbaatar's young men and women would like to wear. With her extra profit, she hopes to open a saving account for her only son.  She requests a Kiva loan to purchase more clothing from Beijing to increase her business inventory.

loans.use: To purchase clothing from Beijing, China

loans.name: Lolita

texts.en:
Mrs. Lolita N., 36 years old, is a resident of Lapasan, Clarin, Mis. Occ. She is married and blessed with four children and her husband is a motorcab driver. Three of her children are already enrolled in the elementary grade and the other one is still a minor dependent.

In order to help her family, she decided to engage in business. Now she has a sari-sari store (variety store) which she opened in October 2008 with an initial capital of only P2,000 with her neighbors as her first customers. To increase her capital, she is applying for an amount of P14,500 as her 3rd loan obtained under the PDP-LP program of Paglaum MPC – Ozamiz Branch. Her future plan for her business is to have a mini grocery store someday. She is also hoping that she can provide a better future for her children.

loans.use: As additional capital for her sari-sari store

loans.name: Yelena

texts.en:
Yelena is married with a grown daughter and a 6-year-old son. She is an entrepreneur from Melitopol where she runs a small business selling women’s clothing and artificial leather retail items in the central city market. Yelena owns three vending facilities in the same marketplace and offers a nice selection of items for sale at prices affordable for an average Ukrainian. Yelena has been running her trade for seven years. She has about 20,000 Grivnyas in turnover capital. Her net profit amounts to 7,000 Grivnyas a month.

Yelena is hoping to use the loan of 12,000 Grivnyas to increase assorted seasonal merchandise and get additional income. She is hoping to invest a portion of the generated income into development of her husband’s construction business startup. Yelena feels very comfortable working in this sphere of business. She has promptly repaid all previous loans and we believe the current loan will be repaid fully as well.

loans.use: To increase seasonal merchandise

loans.name: Manzurabuvi

texts.ru: Манзурабуви – молодая женщина 37 лет, замужем и мать 3-х детей. Её муж занимается купле -продажей скота на скотном рынке. А она откармливает крупнорогатый скот дома. Она помогает мужу в развитии его бизнеса, потому что хочет иметь больше прибыли, чтобы расширять семью, так как в сельских местностях принято рожать больше 3-х детей.  За счет займа они хотят увеличить количество скота и  получить больше прибыли.
texts.en:
Manzurabuvi is a young, 37-year-old woman. She is married and has 3 children. Her husband is involved in livestock sales at the livestock market. And she feeds cattle at home. Manzurabuvi helps her husband with developing his business because they want to have larger profits in order to expand their family. It is customary to have more than 3 children in rural areas. They want to use this loan to increase their livestock quantity and make more profit.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of livestock

loans.name: Fe

texts.en:
Fe J. is from the village of Sta Ana, Aloran, Misamis Occidental. She is 57 years old. Fe is married and has 11 adult children. To make a living, Fe owns and operates a weaving business. The main source of income for the business comes primarily from manufacturing and selling bamboo mats to local community members. Fe has been engaged in her business for more than 10 years and earns approximately 2,000 Philippine pesos (about $50) a month for these activities.

In 2009, Fe joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Fe is requesting a new loan of 4,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase materials to manufacture additional products. This will be the first loan taken out by Fe from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.


*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase materials to manufacture additional products

loans.name: Edith

texts.en:
Señora Edith is 25 years old and lives in a settlement called "Luz y Paz" (Light and Peace) in the city of Pucallpa. Edith has a business selling clothing and basic food staples. She works together with her husband, with whom she has three children. These children give Edith the motivation to keep progressing with her business.

Edith used her very first loan of 300 soles (about $100) to purchase clothing for sale. Edith plans to use this loan of 1000 soles for the same purpose. She and her husband sell their products in the small villages and towns along the banks of the Ucayali, the wide brown river that flows past Pucallpa and eventually joins the Amazon to the north.

Edith is very grateful to Manuela Ramos for helping working women and for educating them about how to run their businesses successfully. The organization's work helps motivate Edith to continue facing life with optimism.

Edith's goals are to grow her business, sell more products and obtain enough money to eventually purchase a piece of land along the river. On this plot of land Edith hopes to grow crops typical of the region.

loans.use: To buy clothing for resale

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth is a member of the Itiji West borrower group in Itiji,Mbeya,she is 30 years old woman,she is  married and a mother of 2 children,Her children are aged 10 and 17 years.

Elizabeth started her own cafe business selling food 1 year ago,she works 8 hours a day and earn monthly profit approximately 150,000 Tanzania shillings.


This is Elizabeth first loan from BRAC_Tanzania,she requested the amount of 100,000 Tsh in order to buy more rice,sugar,salts for food.

With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan Elizabeth hopes to save money,pay school fees,get more food for family and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more rice,cooking oil,sugar,for food

loans.name: Nalwagee Group

texts.en:
Comfort is a 35-year-old woman living in remote Kolahu city in rural Lofa County, Liberia. Comfort’s business is retail beverages, including water, juice, soft drinks and beer, which she buys locally and also imports from nearby Guinea. She sell to the farming community from her temporary market stall in the Kolahu main market alongside approximately 100 other vendors of various trades. She has been running her business for three years.  

Comfort is married with two children, ages 2 and 6. She is also taking care of one child orphaned in the war. Her eldest is in kindergarten. She was forced to drop out of elementary school because, although she enjoyed it, the cultural norm was for girls to rely on their husbands to provide and, therefore, school was considered unnecessary. 

Comfort’s dream is to grow her business so that she can soon have a much bigger stall. She says her business is successful because of the way she treats her customers. She is taking out a loan to buy inventory in larger quantities to meet demand. With the profits from her business, Comfort dreams of sending her children to school, which she was denied.

Nalwagee is a group of five borrowers led by Comfort B., living in Kolahu, Lofa County – the breadbasket of Liberia.

loans.use: To increase inventory of water,  juice and soft drinks

loans.name: Stellamaris Syombua

texts.en:
Stellamaris and her husband Shadrack have three daughters: Faith (six years old), Dorcas (four years old), and Esther (two years old). Stellamaris has been operating a butcher shop for four years. Her area of business is in a highly populated area within eastlands Nairobi. Her target clients are the families living within the area. She also supplies meat to a number of hotels.

Stellamaris was introduced to KADET by existing clients and she has no previous credit history. She would like to use the loan proceeds to renovate her butcher shop by repainting it. With the extra profits she expects to gain, shet plans to open another butchery.

Stellamaris aspires to own a chain of butcheries since she believes she is hardworking and honest enough to bring her goals to reality.

About KADET:

The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empower its clients by providing financial services to improve the living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs across Kenya and their children. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website www.kadet.co.ke.

loans.use: Renovating the butchery premise by repainting it.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: acheter des engrais

loans.name: Samuela

texts.en:
Samuela is married to Julius. She is 30 years old and gifted with two children: Joi Antonette, 10 years old, and Julius Jr., 8 years old. They live peacefully in the village of Palattao, Naguilian, Isabela.

Samuela has been selling frozen foods for four months. She sells them throughout their entire village on a house to house basis. Her starting capital was PHP 2,300; now, she wants to expand her business. She would like to borrow PHP 5,000, which is sufficient to expand her business. She hopes to get the chance to increase her income and thus sustain the growing needs of her family.

loans.use: additional capital with which to grow her business

loans.name: Mrs. Ron Nget Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan, which consists of ten people, is located in Trapeang Khchau village in Takeo province and each member will use the loan for a different purpose. Mrs. Ron N. is the village bank president.

Mrs. Ron N. is a farmer who owns a piece of land on which she cultivates both rice and vegetables. Now she wants to grow vegetables on the field but she does not have enough money. Thus, she decided to ask for a loan to grow beans and soy on the field.

Mrs. Ron N. is 33 years old and the mother of four children, two of whom are attending the local school while the others are too young to work or study. Her husband, Mr. Ou Chheang, is a soldier and he uses the rest of his time as a construction worker.

loans.use: To grow beans and soy on her field

loans.name: Purita

texts.en:
Purita T. lives in the village of Talusan, Brgy. Bulanon, Sagay City, Negros Occidental. She is 56 years-old and married to Romeo who is a 59 year-old fisherman. They have ten children whose ages range from 14 to 36 years-old. The older ones have their own jobs and help their parents support the family, while the younger ones still attend school. Purita works hard to help her husband earn additional income to support their family of 12. She dreams that all of her children will finish their studies and have a good job.

Just like other wives who help their husbands support their family, Purita looked for ways to add on to their capital. In 1998, she joined NWTF-Project Dungganon so that she could have access to capital so that they could buy additional fishing gear and equipment. Later, she and her husband realized that instead of selling the catch to a local vendor wholesale, they could earn more if Purita sold their catch to the community on a retail basis. This decision turned out to be a good idea as it also enabled them to develop good relationships with their regular customers. Now she earns a minimum of Php 6,000 per month from her business activities.

In her last loan she borrowed Php 19,500 as additional working capital for her fishing business. After repaying that loan she now wants to borrow the same amount of PhP 19,500 for her 10th cycle loan to be used to purchase a new fishing boat.

About NWTF:

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: To purchase a new fishing boat.

loans.name: Nancy Yessenia

texts.es:
Nuestra socia YESSENIA es una madre de familia, tiene 32 años de edad, es casada, tienen dos hijos: Santiago tiene 6 años y estudia en el colegio y esta en el nivel primario y Esteban tiene 4 años y esta en el jardín.
